unnormalised: **Delhi Air Quality Remains a Concern Despite Recent Efforts**
normalised: Delhi Air Quality Remains a Concern Despite Recent Efforts

unnormalised: New Delhi – Air quality in the National Capital Territory continues to be a significant environmental challenge, despite recent initiatives aimed at curbing pollution, according to a report released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) on Tuesday. The Air Quality Index (AQI) has consistently remained in the 'Poor' to 'Very Poor' category in several areas, especially during the Diwali season.
normalised: New Delhi – Air quality in the National Capital Territory continues to be a significant environmental challenge, despite recent initiatives aimed at curbing pollution, according to a report released by the Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) on Tuesday. The Air Quality Index (A Q I) has consistently remained in the 'Poor' to 'Very Poor' category in several areas, especially during the Diwali season.

unnormalised: The CPCB report highlighted elevated levels of particulate matter, including PM2.5 and PM10, in areas like Anand Vihar and RK Puram. Vehicle emissions, industrial activity, and construction dust remain major contributors. Experts at IIT Delhi are currently studying the effectiveness of various interventions, including the odd-even scheme.
normalised: The C P C B report highlighted elevated levels of particulate matter, including P M two point five and P M ten, in areas like Anand Vihar and R K Puram. Vehicle emissions, industrial activity, and construction dust remain major contributors. Experts at I I T Delhi are currently studying the effectiveness of various interventions, including the odd-even scheme.

unnormalised: Environmental activist, Sunita Narain, referencing the famous dialogue from the Bollywood film "3 Idiots," stated that simply saying "All is well" will not solve the problem; rigorous implementation of existing regulations is crucial. The Delhi government has announced plans for increased monitoring and stricter enforcement of pollution norms. The current AQI in some regions is as high as 350, posing health risks to vulnerable populations, particularly children and the elderly. Further mitigation strategies are urgently needed.
normalised: Environmental activist, Sunita Narain, referencing the famous dialogue from the Bollywood film "three Idiots," stated that simply saying "All is well" will not solve the problem; rigorous implementation of existing regulations is crucial. The Delhi government has announced plans for increased monitoring and stricter enforcement of pollution norms. The current A Q I in some regions is as high as three hundred and fifty, posing health risks to vulnerable populations, particularly children and the elderly. Further mitigation strategies are urgently needed.
